hackathon-description-text: Build and demo smart city augmented and mixed reality (AR/MR) projects using the Microsoft HoloLens. This free hackathon will have 10+ HoloLenses and some Emulators for you to check out, free food, and prize bundles of tech goodies - including a Microsoft HoloLens!
hackathon-eligibility: Anyone can participate - individuals, teams and organizations. There are no limits on team size.
hackathon-rules:
: Anyone can participate - individuals, teams and organizations. There are no limits on team size.
: 
: You keep any and all intellectual property you bring or build for this challenge. We only ask that winners allow us to use their names in marketing and press about the event.
: Winners will be picked by a panel of judges and prize bundles will be awarded at their discretion. 
: We will have some equipment and supplies at the event you can hack on, including about 20 HoloLenses.  Participants are expected to bring their own computers, software and development environments. Read our suggestions about that here: 
: Both brand new and existing projects are eligible.
: Contestants can submit more than one project.
: We promise to create a safe environment for you. We address every code of conduct violation regardless of severity (severity, after all, is subjective) and we do so in a respectful way to all parties using a transparent process. Please read our Code of Conduct here: 
.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Microsoft Hololens (Developer Edition), LucidSound LS30 Wireless Universal Gaming Headset, three Amazon Echo Dots
XBOX ONE Elite, LucidSound LS30 Wireless Universal Gaming Headset, two Amazon Echo Dots
XBOX ONE Elite, LucidSound LS30 Wireless Universal Gaming Headset, Amazon Echo Dot
XBox Live Gold Annual Subscriptions for every team member
32" Samsung Smart TV / Monitor, two Amazon Echo Dots

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=848 Spring St NW, Atlanta, GA 30308, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Wow factor. Did you build something no one thought was possible? Did you use techniques that are abnormal, often impractical, and weirdly elegant?
Is it easy to understand? Is it easy to use? Is it creative?

hackathon-location-address: 848 Spring St NW, Atlanta, GA 30308, USA
hackathon-description-header: An AR/MR smart cities hackathon with thyssenkrupp & Microsoft HoloLens
